import React from 'react'; export default function Chorechat() { return (

Chorechat summary

Background

I currently live in a house with 3 other roommates and while we are all generally tidy and keep our house pretty clean, we've never instituted an official chore duty roster and so there are certainly things that have been neglected - grime around the bathroom sink that's been allowed to build up a bit beyond what's acceptable, crumbs littering the counter around our toaster, etc.

I consulted with my roommates and asked them if they'd be interested in an automated chore scheduler with weekly duty alerts sent to each person's phone.

They said yes. So I built one.

Project Description

Compared to the other projects documented here on my portfolio, Chorechat is relatively simple and straightforward. It's a purely server based application with no need for a front end.

Lessons Learned

Reading through the Twilio documentation, I discovered their recommendation to make use of ngrok.com to help with local testing as it redirects Twilio's webhook from a live ngrok URL to your machine's local server. A really cool and super helpful tool for testing out your messaging protocols.

) }
